Or it costs them too much

Actually saw on a previous post on this topic that it's more a supply issue, at least here in the UK. in a year or two it will be 50% recycled plastic in the bottles with the aim of increasing further when supply allows. Granted that's their corporate response so pinch of salt et al.

Hi Russell, We’d like to use more but there’s not enough recycled plastic in the UK at the moment, more bottles need to be recycled. At the moment, we use 25% recycled plastic in every one of our bottles here in Great Britain and we’re committed to doubling the amount to 50% in the next three years.

Hi Oskars, that is not the case. For the last five years, we’ve been using 25% recycled plastic across all our brands, a figure we want to increase to 50% by 2020, but there’s not enough recycled plastic to go beyond that in Great Britain at the moment. This is why as part of our strategy we will be seeking reform of the recycling system in the UK to improve recovery and recycling rates. We are continually evolving our recycling strategy and investing in innovations to support our overall sustainability commitments.
So Coca Cola, why did you oppose a deposit return scheme? From my self confessed limited knowledge, did not the Scottish government pressure you into a trial?
If there's not enough recycled plastic then how is it that Ribena have been making their bottles from 100% recycled plastic since 2007?

Hi Russell, we have always said that we’re not against anything that improves recycling and recovery rates and reduces litter. We’ve been involved in the implementation of well-designed deposit schemes around the world and we’ve seen the positive impact they can have. It’s true that we’ve expressed concerns about deposit return schemes. Whilst some concerns remain, it’s clear that recycling rates have stalled and there’s a need to address the issue of recycling and on-the-go littering and we believe we should try something different. For more, read here: http://spr.ly/61858QOUf
